data.text: Schnabel: Inflation is well below our aim of below, but close to, 2% and is expected to fall further due to COVID-19. Stable prices are crucial for the economy. Deflation would harm European citizens, including through lower wages and higher unemployment. #AskECB https://t.co/QC2hjRPYlh

Schnabel: The Eurosystem holds close to 20% of the green bonds eligible for our corporate bond purchase programmes. Our purchases have lowered yields and supported issuance. The more green bonds are issued, the more we can buy. #AskECB https://t.co/mdjnJadeIB

Schnabel: To support policy transmission, we have introduced a two-tier system. This means that a multiple of banks’ minimum reserves are remunerated at the main refinancing rate (0%); the remaining excess reserves are remunerated at the deposit facility rate (-0.5%). #AskECB https://t.co/tKxtg61yOV

Schnabel: No. We have ample evidence that our measures are effective in easing financing conditions in the economy. Our measures have supported economic growth and inflation. #AskECB https://t.co/ycZcQLmipg

Schnabel: The current crisis will lead to an increase in unemployment. Those who are at risk of losing their jobs are likely to benefit most from our measures. This includes many young people. #AskECB https://t.co/ClzpyGs8sk

Schnabel: As all major central banks, we have responded to this unprecedented crisis by expanding our balance sheet. Further monetary policy decisions will be guided by our mandate of price stability. The @ecb will stop purchases when appropriate. #AskECB https://t.co/E04pti48H3

Schnabel: The @ecb’s inflation aim of below, but close to, 2% has served us well for the past 20 years. In our monetary policy strategy review, we will assess whether it remains appropriate for the future: https://t.co/8WglnlI995 #AskECB https://t.co/nRBvogkBp3

Schnabel: An easing of monetary policy tends to raise asset prices, which lowers the costs of funding, including for equity. Especially start-up firms rely on functioning capital markets. The ECB is promoting the development of a European Capital Markets Union. #AskECB https://t.co/aD4zG7Tqpn

Schnabel: Our decisions since March 2020 have provided important support to the real economy. Should conditions deteriorate, we have the necessary tools at our disposal to react to any contingency, as we have done since the start of the crisis. #AskECB https://t.co/QAyxcAaoQF

Schnabel: Our purchases are conducted in a way that maintains market functioning. This excludes holding everything. The prohibition of monetary financing is and will remain an important basis of monetary policy in the euro area. #AskECB https://t.co/jheWtlDSgY

Schnabel: The ECB receives interest income on its asset holdings. Profits are distributed to the national central banks of the euro area, which are the ECB’s shareholders. The profits are reported in the annual accounts: https://t.co/zgTiYKozQ6. #AskECB https://t.co/fl5Domoa9g

Schnabel: Monetary policy has raised inflation. But structural factors like globalisation, lower growth in energy prices and changes in competition weigh on inflation, requiring central banks to be more patient, as argued in a recent speech: https://t.co/r3WBsL9tpo. #AskECB https://t.co/jmJD8pKVEj

Schnabel: Absolutely. Keeping prices stable preserves the purchasing power of European citizens and supports investment and job creation by reducing uncertainty. This is particularly important in the current crisis. #AskECB https://t.co/py5xqggZze

Schnabel: On question 2: Transparency and open communication are important strategic priorities for the @ecb. #PEPP purchases are not a secret. We publish granular information on these purchases on a bimonthly basis, most recently in early June: https://t.co/UWeApCMAhZ #AskECB https://t.co/rb2KSmRgOI

Schnabel: This claim is not correct. The HICP used by @ecb is calculated by @EU_Eurostat, the statistical office of the European Union. Some prices like food have increased more strongly recently, which can give the impression that prices rise faster than they do. #AskECB https://t.co/2uaRxKOmJG

Schnabel: Aber genau das mache ich doch gerade. Mir ist die Kommunikation mit den europäischen Bürgerinnen und Bürgern sehr wichtig. [But this is exactly what I am doing. Communication with the European citizens is very important to me.] #AskECB https://t.co/VM55VMtN7y

Schnabel: This is indeed a political question. Note, however, that our mandate already includes aspects like full employment and the protection of the environment, as long as these do not stand in conflict with our primary objective of price stability. #AskECB https://t.co/gJ7ufllFSX

Schnabel: Given the favourable pricing, we expect a sizeable take-up next week (allotment on Thursday, 18 June). The TLTROs are successful if banks use the funds to grant loans to the real economy. #AskECB https://t.co/DJeIAaIDOW

Schnabel: Our staff is intellectually and culturally diverse, and we encourage open discussions within the institution. Broad external interaction with economists with diverse backgrounds ensures full exposure to different streams of monetary thinking. #AskECB https://t.co/Rq3vPHqKqm

Schnabel: Our public sector asset purchases are guided by the capital key. Our pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) offers the flexibility to deviate from the capital key as required to ensure a smooth transmission of our monetary policy to the entire euro area. #AskECB https://t.co/Th1qDXtwn0

Schnabel: The advantages and disadvantages of price level targeting and average inflation targeting are going to be considered in the context of our monetary policy strategy review. As President Lagarde said: “We will not leave any stone unturned.” #AskECB https://t.co/ScAQVTeHNK

Schnabel: The expansion of the ACC framework is a temporary response to the pandemic, which allows banks to make full use of our liquidity operations, so they can continue lending to the real economy. See our recent blog post on collateral https://t.co/mqvscOw93b #AskECB https://t.co/Auc7FMyaBQ

Schnabel: Cash continues to be very popular in the euro area, with some differences across member states. We are always ready to explore innovations like digital currencies, but there is no intention to abandon cash. #AskECB https://t.co/WZIjLCkvAE

Schnabel: What is important to me is price stability. Both too high and too low inflation can lead to high costs for society. That’s why we are mandated by the Treaty to keep prices stable. In recent years, inflation has been too low and is projected to fall even further. #AskECB https://t.co/R91Fc7pDMK

Schnabel: Internal models are a well-accepted tool in banking supervision. To mitigate incentive problems, supervisors carefully check these models. The acceptance of internal ratings is a temporary measure to relieve the strains from the COVID-19 pandemic. #AskECB https://t.co/6FnQVarexy
@AlvariISLM @adam_tooze @Shahinvallee @FrancescoPapad1

Schnabel: In #PEPP national central banks receive guidance about the amounts to be purchased, guided by the capital key but with flexibility. With respect to maturities, purchases are guided by market neutrality. Therefore they also depend on issuance behaviour. #AskECB https://t.co/h91HvkDmdX

Schnabel: Climate protection is a key topic in our monetary policy strategy review, which will be resumed shortly. We will analyse the role of climate change for our economic models, investment portfolios, risk assessments and monetary policy operations. #AskECB https://t.co/VUzSdLEhA3

Schnabel: Our monetary policy actions are guided by our price stability mandate. We will adjust our measures when medium-term inflation recovers in a sustainable way, always taking into account the risks to financial stability and other potential side effects. #AskECB https://t.co/AnTP9p3oXJ

Schnabel: I beg to differ. Our measures have been beneficial for consumers as they contributed to higher wages and created jobs. Income inequality has even decreased, as poorer households have benefited more from the positive employment effects. #AskECB https://t.co/nBD47K7gso

Schnabel: We have a clear mandate – price stability –, which is laid down in the Treaties. We are subject to the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice. And don’t underestimate our accountability towards the European Parliament, which is actually quite important. #AskECB https://t.co/O0IH6L8Yo1

Schnabel: This question has to be analysed by comparing actual inflation with a counterfactual situation without QE. Based on empirical data, our analyses show that the effect of QE on inflation has been positive, see https://t.co/cGJbNCOyTp
#AskECB https://t.co/tc53F7QfMz

Schnabel: We proactively monitor current developments in the area of stablecoins, assessing regulatory and financial stability implications: https://t.co/NFX1xMDX0R. At the same time, we are open to innovation, including in the area of digital currencies. #AskECB https://t.co/fXVaLPXf1k

Schnabel: The negative deposit facility rate lowers funding costs for the whole economy. Offering more attractive conditions in TLTROs is an effective way to foster bank lending to households and firms. The tiering system reduces side effects on bank profitability. #AskECB https://t.co/5VB7V6tzqi

Schnabel: Our policies primarily support healthy and promising firms. The share of unviable firms has declined in many countries. Bank health matters more for firm quality than monetary policy, see https://t.co/sZDjqWOTcs. #AskECB https://t.co/2A1GX3HiFg

Schnabel: There is no evidence that our purchase programmes have delayed economic reforms. In the COVID-19 crisis, fiscal & monetary policy are complementary. Our policies support reform efforts through their beneficial effect on funding costs. #AskECB https://t.co/TbAjzCB9BY

Schnabel: The Eurosystem currently holds around 9% of its balance sheet in the form of gold and gold receivables: https://t.co/YL4O1oPAgn. Gold is an important foreign reserve asset that is held for liquidity and risk diversification purposes. #AskECB https://t.co/nodkVFafxE

Schnabel: We counter too high as well as too low inflation in a symmetric way. By focusing on the medium term, we can adjust the speed of returning to our inflation aim, thereby mitigating the side effects of our measures, including on member states, firms and households. #AskECB https://t.co/2PP7kaFmOo
Schnabel: Empirical evidence does not support this statement. #QE has even slightly reduced wealth inequality in the euro area, see https://t.co/CjRjg1YHkZ #AskECB https://t.co/XXFIfNxiq3
Good afternoon, this is @Isabel_Schnabel, Executive Board member @ecb. I’m here to answer your questions for the next 45 minutes. Please use #AskECB to join the conversation. https://t.co/ebv5xJCciN

Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Zanni, Ms Donato, Mr Grant and Mr Rinaldi, MEPs, on bank provisioning for non-performing loans https://t.co/yAFQa2MrD7 (EN) https://t.co/4IaEzGmf8x (IT)

The international role of the euro is primarily supported by a deeper and more complete Economic and Monetary Union, said President Lagarde during our last monetary policy press conference. Read her foreword to the report https://t.co/YjLLE7I6kX https://t.co/4xpOCKg9vr

The report also highlights the significant role of the euro in global green bond markets, with the euro being the main currency of denomination for the issuance of green bonds in 2019. More info in Box 1 https://t.co/N0cOLC071s https://t.co/ezMK25o7dQ

Since its introduction 20 years ago the euro has remained unchallenged as the world’s second most widely used currency, after the US dollar. Read our full report on the international role of the euro https://t.co/gvNmSrm5PK

President @Lagarde is now speaking to @EP_Economics members in her capacity as Chair of the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB).

➡️ Opening remarks https://t.co/4v8AJJCV7W
➡️ Press release on the latest ESRB policy actions in response to coronavirus https://t.co/dqytitX8bD
Lagarde: Our common response to this crisis, if used to effectively direct investment towards strategic priority areas, can be a catalyst for realising Europe’s longer-term vision.

Lagarde: We have the opportunity to step up the EU’s efforts to achieve its sustainability objectives by including climate change and sustainability considerations in the financial response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Lagarde: The crisis can be an opportunity to modernise our economies to make them fit for the future. The transition towards a greener economy is a crucial part of this.

Lagarde: The ECB measures will continue to be crucial in supporting the return of inflation towards our medium-term inflation aim after the worst of the crisis has passed and the euro area economy begins its journey to economic recovery.

Lagarde: The measures we have taken in response to the COVID-19 crisis underscore the Governing Council’s continued determination and readiness to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a sustained manner.

Lagarde: Taken together, two main factors called for additional monetary policy easing: the deteriorating inflation outlook threatening our medium-term price stability objective and the unwarranted tightening of financial conditions.

Lagarde: The monetary policy measures taken by the ECB in March were critical in removing the tail risk of the COVID-19 pandemic and the ensuing drop in economic activity morphing into a financial crisis. Since March, that risk has receded materially.
Lagarde: After a contraction in GDP of 3.8% in the first quarter of the year, our new staff projections see it shrinking by 13% in the second quarter.
Lagarde: The COVID-19 pandemic and measures to contain the spread of the virus have caused an unprecedented contraction of economic activity in the euro area.
Introductory statement by Christine @Lagarde at a hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/XDkonLDm20

Coming up in 15 mins: ECB President Christine @Lagarde’s quarterly hearing before the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs @EP_Economics. Follow live from 15:45 CET https://t.co/8uAsHpafbH https://t.co/W6R8X70h8G
EU structural financial indicators (end of 2019) https://t.co/cAdzb4uJ5b
Read our full response to the @EU_Commission public consultations on the Renewed Sustainable Finance Strategy and the Non-Financial Reporting Directive https://t.co/1770e3Yzl3

We have identified five key priorities in our response: improving disclosure and closing data gaps, developing the right incentives for sustainable investments, monitoring risks, exploiting synergies with the capital markets union and boosting international cooperation.

The ECB and euro area national central banks support the @EU_Commission in strengthening sustainable finance and improving financial disclosure. This effort is key to incorporating environmental and social sustainability into the financial response to the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/xHpc1YQDdH

Fabio Panetta, membro del comitato esecutivo della BCE, ha parlato a @MediasetTgcom24 delle ultime decisioni di politica monetaria e della situazione economica dell’area dell’euro. Guarda il servizio qui https://t.co/QBjUALAsRE

Panetta sui pacchetti di strumenti dell'Unione Europea: la maggiore tranquillità che possiamo percepire sui mercati è frutto di tutte le decisioni prese dalle autorità nazionali ed europee. Leggi l'intervista https://t.co/tXuagSoeD7 o ascoltala qui https://t.co/zG5i54o61k 3/3

Panetta sulle previsioni di crescita: prima della pandemia erano poco meno di un punto percentuale. Oggi si parla di una crescita negativa per oltre otto punti e mezzo percentuali. Non pubblichiamo le previsioni per i singoli Paesi, ma l’Italia seguirà un andamento analogo 2/3

L’inflazione è molto bassa, e si prevede che lo rimanga ancora nel prossimo biennio, ha spiegato Fabio Panetta, Membro del Comitato esecutivo della BCE, in un'intervista con @Radio1Rai parlando dell'espansione del programma di acquisti di titoli della BCE 1/3 https://t.co/byQAhLjQ9U

We will not allow a tightening of financial conditions to further weigh on the euro area economy, said Executive Board member Fabio Panetta to @Radio1Rai, talking about the latest monetary policy measures and the economic growth outlook. Read the interview https://t.co/rzgDHLzkdg https://t.co/Assru0ChNS
ECB concludes comprehensive assessment of five Croatian banks https://t.co/b9VIxB1ID4
A similar health check was carried out for UBS and Bank of America subsidiaries relocating due to Brexit. Neither of the two banks faces any capital shortfall https://t.co/nAGKLHR8En 2/2

(THREAD) The ECB has concluded its comprehensive assessment of five Croatian banks following Croatia’s request to join European banking supervision. The exercise did not reveal capital shortfalls https://t.co/Oq1IQIGLdt 1/2
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Sven Giegold, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/MZgNkgvUvx
ECB and National Bank of Romania set up repo line to provide euro liquidity https://t.co/uFokYvhTde

In a post on #TheECBBlog, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses the outlook for growth and inflation in the euro area as well as yesterday’s decision to expand the size of the pandemic emergency purchase programme https://t.co/KlfzWCu22n https://t.co/tkkGnq4joi
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (April 2020) https://t.co/n8LqHh8OzA
Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s monetary policy press conference https://t.co/0NlvObj1gK https://t.co/JAEl4rEibd
Watch again: Lagarde on the German Federal Constitutional Court ruling https://t.co/uhXQfprYE1
Watch again: Lagarde on why we had to act today https://t.co/LLMxsJiCko
What would you like to ask ECB Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel? Post your question using #AskECB and follow her answers live on Tuesday 9 June. https://t.co/uJNVp4X9WP

Eurosystem staff macroeconomic projections for the euro area (June 2020) https://t.co/16Cl7jZfdk

Projection charts and tables https://t.co/htm2ED6q0T https://t.co/MdSwYMcj1K
Introductory statement by President Christine Lagarde to the press conference https://t.co/0NlvObj1gK
ECB President Christine Lagarde introduces the baseline GDP and inflation outlook for the euro area. https://t.co/45hE6goour
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions https://t.co/KmtpDuXRUQ
Coming up in 15 minutes: ECB President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/uHP8faKs3l
Press release: Monetary policy decisions https://t.co/MmOdsWpzNn
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/Q3N929cSJq
Euro area insurance corporation statistics (Q1 2020) https://t.co/Op9NRepHGT

Applications for our Women in Economics #Scholarship close next week. We are offering grants and a study visit at the ECB to female #economics students. Like last year’s winners pictured here, you need to be an EU national with top undergraduate marks https://t.co/X1Tyfv4t8M https://t.co/RPKQiE06q6

Recently, the ECB Archives released over 400 documents that played a role in the drafting of the Delors report, which laid out the roadmap for the creation of the euro. This is the first time that these records are being made available online https://t.co/A96NvgR9rt https://t.co/toDS7NFyWn
We have also put in place a set of banking supervision measures to help banks support the economy. Read what they mean for euro area citizens https://t.co/tDtOp3YYdB

We aim to help euro area citizens and firms get access to funds they need during the #coronavirus crisis by lowering borrowing costs and increasing lending in the euro area. Find all our measures explained in 23 EU languages https://t.co/HJzEtFpSSL https://t.co/kST1KYJP9S

The measures the ECB has taken to limit the impact of the coronavirus have been effective so far in calming markets but uncertainty remains high, explains ECB Board member @Isabel_Schnabel in #TheECBPodcast. Listen to her discussion with @MichaelSteen https://t.co/XKlV6ObIvp https://t.co/UtR9Kkusaf
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in April? How do they compare with March’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/pHttUalZgo https://t.co/uOrRYlT5iM

As European banking supervisor we have also taken supervisory decisions that aim to support lending to the economy. We want to ensure that firms and households have access to credit and encourage banks to do their part https://t.co/tDtOp3YYdB

The #coronavirus is having a profound effect on our economy. We have put in place a variety of measures to support people and business across the euro area. How? Discover our measures in 23 EU languages on our website https://t.co/HJzEtFpSSL https://t.co/jPRsrSulGv

Presentation Edouard Fernandez-Bollo: European banking supervision measures in the context of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic
https://t.co/s6cecpZY4e

Why is the ECB activating swap lines during the pandemic? How do such agreements affect market participants? Find out the answers to these questions and more in our latest #podcast with host @MichaelSteen and ECB Board member @Isabel_Schnabel https://t.co/XKlV6OtjTZ https://t.co/NOPtNZxtCx

President Lagarde gave an insight into how European leaders have been working together towards a common response to the coronavirus pandemic in an online Q&A for @Europarl_EYE. https://t.co/idm0Xr6bbo

Countries have had to increase their debt in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, but what is important is how that money is spent. This was President Lagarde’s message in today’s Q&A for @Europarl_EYE when asked what higher debt levels mean for the eurozone. https://t.co/Ja5XiGxHt4

Today in an online Q&A for @Europarl_EYE, President Lagarde thanked the true heroes in the fight against the coronavirus: doctors, nurses, ambulance drivers and those who risk their lives in order to save ours. https://t.co/gXqwrQdOWW

Interview @Isabel_Schnabel with Perspektiven der Wirtschaftspolitik

English:
https://t.co/vG2cvCJMwK

Our colleague Georgina asked President Lagarde questions on topics such as the economic impact of the coronavirus and climate change. 

Watch the event on our YouTube channel https://t.co/XgvVs3zMYt https://t.co/WLqR4giUop

Tune in at 13:00 CET to watch ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria speak about the ECB’s supervisory response to the coronavirus at the Institute of International Finance virtual European Conference https://t.co/bbZR5U0Qts https://t.co/bYMRdY1rhB
